Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Award: DMS 1406167, Principal Investigator: Mark E. Feighn

Two projects are proposed in the area of geometric group theory, a relatively young subfield of mathematics where problems from other areas of math are reformulated in geometric terms and then (hopefully) solved using a geometer's toolkit. This approach has been successful in solving problems in such diverse areas as combinatorial group theory (think of a situation such as Rubik's cube where a discrete set of moves is allowed) and logic. Both projects are focused on a particular group of classical interest called "the outer automorphism group of a free group" which is denoted Out(F). Groups arise as sets of symmetries of objects and Out(F) is the set of symmetries of a free group F, an important group from which all others can be constructed. Completion of either project would represent a major advance in the field.

The first project, joint with Mladen Bestvina at the University of Utah, is to continue the study of the geometry of Out(F). In particular, we have a plan to show that Out(F) has finite asymptotic dimension. Part of this work will also be joint with Patrick Reynolds at the University of Utah. The geometry of Out(F) is currently a hot topic with interest spurred in large part by results of Bestvina-Feighn and Handel-Mosher that certain spaces on which Out(F) acts are hyperbolic. The second project, joint with Michael Handel at Lehman College, is to show that Out(F) has a solvable conjugacy problem. The conjugacy problem is a famous decidability question formulated by Max Dehn around 1911 that can be asked about any group. The fact that it remains open for Out(F) reveals a gap in our basic understanding of this group.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is in an area of mathematics called geometric group theory. Here problems from other areas of math are translated in to geometric terms and then (hopefully) solved using a geometer's toolkit. To get the idea, consider the visual intuition gained by viewing real numbers as points on the number line, or the solutions to x2+y2+z2=1 as the unit sphere. This idea is classical, but has recently been successful in solving problems from areas as diverse as group theory and logic.

We are interested in solving problems from group theory. An example of a group is the set of symmetries of an object. For example, the symmetries of an equilateral triangle forms a group with six elements. In fact, all groups arise in this fashion. In geometric group theory, information about a group is obtained by studying the related object. In the problems proposed in this grant, both the groups and the associated objects are infinite.

 I will next describe the groups of interest in this project. There is a class of groups called free groups and denoted Fn. There is one for each natural number n. F1 is the familiar set of integers, but for n>1, Fn is more complicated. Free groups are of utmost importance because there is a sense in which all groups can be obtained from free groups. We are interested in the group Out(Fn), which can be interpreted as the set of symmetries of Fn itself. These groups rose to prominence more than 100 years ago and are of great current interest.

In 1911 Max Dehn proposed 3 famous questions that can be posed for any family of groups. There is only one of these questions, the conjugacy problem, that remains open for Out(Fn). This was one of our proposed problems. Little progress had been made on this problem. It breaks naturally into two pieces, Michael Handel and I recently submitted a long paper with a solution to one of these pieces, representing a good step forward.

Out(Fn) may be studied as symmetries of an object called the free splitting complex. Sometimes it becomes easier to understand an object if one can identify points at infinity. For example, if we add one point at infinity to a plane then we get a sphere. This reflects the perception that the world we live on is flat. Another proposed question was to identify the points at infinity for the free splitting complex. Mladen Bestvina, Patrick Reynolds, and I did just that and are in the process of writing up this result. Some fascinating, never-before-seen phenomena arose in the solution.

Much of the broader impact of this work comes from the new techniques introduced and/or developed. In the work on the conjugacy problem, Handel and I developed the theory of relative train tracks. This gives improved ways to understand individual elements of Out(Fn). Our theory of these improved relative train tracks is becoming a standard tool in the study of Out(Fn). In the work with Bestvina and Reynolds, we introduced new techniques for understanding the geometry of Outer space. Outer space is another space on which Out(Fn) acts by symmetries and is closely related to the free splitting complex. The study of the geometry of Outer space is a relatively new approach to understanding Out(Fn) and is another topic of intense current interest.

Other broader impacts relate to the training of young researchers in the field. For example, during the grant period: Pei Wang completed her PhD under my direction; I gave talks to young researchers on topics related to the proposal; I was lead organizer of a jumbo program in geometric group theory at the Mathematical Sciences Reseach Institute; and I served as an editor for Transactions of the AMS and for Memoirs of the AMS.
